{{For|sport-themed board games based on fantasy fiction|Fantasy football (board games)}}
A '''fantasy sport''' (also known less commonly as '''rotisserie''' or '''roto''') is a type of online game where participants assemble imaginary or virtual teams of real players of a professional sport.  These teams compete based on the statistical performance of those players' players in actual games.  This performance is converted into points that are compiled and totaled according to a roster selected by each fantasy team's manager.  These point systems can be simple enough to be manually calculated by a "league commissioner" who coordinates and manages the overall league, or points can be compiled and calculated using computers tracking actual results of the professional sport.  In fantasy sports, team owners draft, trade and cut (drop) players, analogously to real sports.

Simulation games such as [[Strat-O-Matic]] are not considered fantasy sport, because they are not scored using real results of actual sporting events.

==History==

===Early history===

The concept of picking players and running a contest based on their year-to-date stats has been around since shortly after [[World War II]]. One of the earliest published accounts of fantasy sports involved [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] businessman and one time [[Oakland Raiders]] limited partner Wilfred "Bill" Winkenbach.  He devised [[fantasy golf]] in the latter part of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsnet5.com/sports/wink-wilfred-bill-winkenbach-invented-fantasy-football-way-back-in-1962-with-gopppl-in-oakland|title='Wink': Wilfred 'Bill' Winkenbach invented Fantasy Football way back in 1962 with GOPPPL in Oakland|publisher=newsnet5.com|date=2014-09-11|accessdate=2015-09-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929163914/http://www.newsnet5.com/sports/wink-wilfred-bill-winkenbach-invented-fantasy-football-way-back-in-1962-with-gopppl-in-oakland|archivedate=2015-09-29|df=}}</ref>  Each player selected a team of professional golfers and the person with the lowest combined total of strokes at the end of the tournament would win.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Golf is a simple fantasy game to administer and keep tabs on, since each participant is concerned only with the scores of his or her team members without anything else to complicate it. However, it was never organized into a widespread hobby or formal business.

In Oakland in 1962, Winkenbach formed the first reported [[Fantasy football (American)|fantasy football]] league, called the Greater Oakland Professional Pigskin Prognosticators League (GOPPPL), with eight teams.<ref>{{cite news | first=Jon | last=Saraceno | coauthors= | title=As fantasy football fever continues to spread, it's not all geeks to me | date=2006-08-17 | publisher= | url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/columnist/saraceno/2006-08-17-saraceno-fantasy-football_x.htm | work =USA Today | pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-17 | language = }}</ref> [[George Blanda]] was the first player taken in the first draft in 1963.
[http://www.nflplayers.com/fantasy/gopppl_draft.htm 1963 draft results]

The first reported [[fantasy baseball]] league began in Boston in 1960. [[Harvard University]] [[sociologist]] [[William A. Gamson|William Gamson]] started the "Baseball Seminar" where colleagues would form rosters that earned points on the players' final standings in batting average, [[Run batted in|RBI]], [[Earned run average|ERA]] and wins.<ref name="The Numbers Game p. 175">[[Alan Schwarz]]: ''The Numbers Game : Baseball's Lifelong Fascination with Statistics'' [[Thomas Dunne Books]] p. 175, {{ISBN|0-312-32222-4}}</ref> Gamson later brought the idea with him to the [[University of Michigan]] where some professors played the game. One professor playing the game was Bob Sklar, who taught an American Studies seminar which included [[Daniel Okrent]], who learned of the game his professor played.<ref name="The Numbers Game p. 175"/> At around the same time a league from [[Rowan University|Glassboro State College]] also formed a similar baseball league and had its first draft in 1976.<ref>{{cite news
 |first=Ed 
 |last=Hilt 
 |coauthors= 
 |title=Fantasy baseball league owners still bonding in their 32nd season 
 |date=2007-06-26 
 |publisher= 
 |url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/local/story/7487701p-7382875c.html 
 |work=Press of Atlantic City 
 |pages= 
 |accessdate=2007-07-17 
 |language= 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704103821/http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/local/story/7487701p-7382875c.html 
 |archivedate=2007-07-04 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |df= 
}}</ref>

===Modern founding of rotisserie===

An important development in fantasy sports came with the development of Rotisserie League Baseball in 1980 (although research 
suggests a team of players from Southern New Jersey have been running the same style league since 1976 making them the first Rotisserie players).{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}  Magazine writer/editor [[Daniel Okrent]] is credited with inventing it, the name coming from the New York City restaurant La Rotisserie Francaise where he and some friends used to meet and play.<ref>{{cite news | first=Lisa | last=Tozzi | coauthors= | title=The Great Pretenders | year=1999 | publisher=The Austin Chronicle | url =http://weeklywire.com/ww/07-05-99/austin_xtra_feature2.html | work = | pages = | accessdate =2008-12-16 | language = }}</ref>  The game's innovation was that "owners" in a Rotisserie league would draft teams from the list of active Major League Baseball players and would follow their statistics during the ongoing season to compile their scores.  In other words, rather than running realistic simulations using statistics for seasons whose outcomes were already known, the owners would have to make similar predictions about players' playing time, health, and expected performance that real baseball managers must make.

Because Okrent was a member of the media, other journalists, especially sports journalists, were introduced to the game. Many early players were introduced to the game by these sports journalists, especially during the [[1981 Major League Baseball strike]]; with little else to write about, many baseball writers wrote columns about Rotisserie league.  A July 8, 1980 New York Times Article titled "What George Steinbrenner is to the American League, Lee Eisenberg is to the Rotisseries League" set off a media storm that led to stories about the league on CBS TV and other publications.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Walker | coauthors= | title=Fantasyland | year=2006 | publisher=Viking | url =http://www.fantasyland.com | work = | page =145 | accessdate = 2007-07-17 | language = }}</ref>

In March 1981, Dan Okrent wrote an essay about the Rotisserie League for [[Inside Sports]] called "The Year George Foster Wasn't Worth $36."<ref>{{cite news | first=Sam | last=Walker | coauthors= | title=Fantasyland | year=2006 | publisher=Viking | url =http://www.fantasyland.com | work = | page =70 | accessdate = 2007-07-17 | language = }}</ref> The article included the rules of the game. Founders of the original Rotisserie league published a guide book starting in 1984.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} In 1982, Ballantine published the first widely available [[Bill James]] Abstract, which helped fuel fantasy baseball interest. Fantasy fans often used James' statistical tools and analysis as a way to improve their teams.<ref name="moneyball">[[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]]: ''Moneyball: the art of winning an unfair game'' [[W. W. Norton]], [[New York City|New York]] c2003., {{ISBN|0-393-05765-8}}</ref> James was not a fantasy player and barely acknowledged fantasy baseball in his annual Abstract, but fantasy baseball interest is credited with his strong sales.<ref name="moneyball"/>

In 1988, [[USA Today]] estimated that there were thousands of leagues in the US, typically 8 to 12 players.<ref name="USAT1">{{cite news|last1=Shushter|first1=Rachel|title=The game is fantasy but the addiction is real|agency=USA Today|date=May 12, 1988}}</ref> The hobby had spread to football as well.<ref name="USAT2">{{cite news|title=Football's in the air via fantasy leagues|agency=USA Today|date=August 12, 1988}}</ref>

===Growth and early participants===

In the few years after Okrent helped popularize fantasy baseball, a host of experts and businesses emerged to service the growing hobby. Okrent, based on discussions with colleagues at USA Today, credits Rotisserie league baseball with much of USA Today's early success,{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} since the paper provided much more detailed box scores than most competitors and eventually even created a special paper, ''[[Sports Weekly|Baseball Weekly]]'', that almost exclusively contained statistics and box scores.

The first experts on record as having written fantasy baseball articles for USA Today were John Benson, Alex Patton, and Ron Shandler.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} Perhaps the most well-known fantasy baseball expert in the late 1980s and early 1990s was Benson, who published his first fantasy baseball book in 1989. Later that year Benson developed the first draft-simulation program, software that he still sells today.<ref>{{cite book |title=Fantasyland |last=Walker |first=Sam |year=2007 |publisher=Penguin Books |page=110|isbn= 0143038435}}</ref>

Patton published his first book ("Patton's 1989 Fantasy Baseball League Price Guide") in 1989 and his dollar values were included in USA Today Baseball Weekly's fantasy annual throughout the 1990s.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
[[Ron Shandler]] published his "Baseball SuperSTATS" book in November 1986. At first the book wasn't meant for fantasy 
baseball fans, but rather as a book of Sabermetric analysis.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

Fantasy football also saw new businesses and growth. Fantasy Football Index became the first annual fantasy football guide in 1987. Fantasy Sports Magazine debuted in 1989 as the first regular publication covering more than one fantasy sport. Fantasy Football Weekly was launched in 1992 (later becoming [[Fanball|Fanball.com]]) and had $2 million in revenue by 1999.<ref>{{cite news | first=Jim | last=Martyka | coauthors= | title=Fantasy fans get new outlet | date= 2000-02-28 | publisher=American City Business Journals | url =http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/1999/09/13/story3.html | work =Minneapolis / St. Paul Business Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref> A large number of companies emerged to calculate the stats for fantasy leagues and primarily send results via fax.

In 1993, USA Today included a weekly columnist on fantasy baseball, John Hunt, and he became perhaps the most visible writer in the industry before the rise of the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.netshrine.com/jhunt.html |title=NetShrine was privileged to interview USA Today Baseball Weekly Fantasy Insider columnist John Hunt |accessdate=2007-07-28 |date=2000-06-25 |work=NetShrine |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024943/http://www.netshrine.com/jhunt.html |archivedate=2007-09-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Hunt started the first high-profile experts league, the [[LABR|League of Alternate Baseball Reality]] which first included notables as [[Peter Gammons]], [[Keith Olbermann]] and [[Bill James]].<ref name="LABR">{{cite news
| first=Jonah
| last=Keri
| title='Tis the season to project stats
| url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=keri/070214
| publisher=ESPN.com
| year=2007
}}</ref>

The hobby continued to grow with 1 million to 3 million playing from 1991 to 1994.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

===Modern times===

====Internet boom====

A large factor in the growth of fantasy sports was the rise of the Internet and personal computers in the mid-1990s. The new technology lowered the barrier to entry to the hobby as stats could quickly be compiled online and news and information became readily available.

In 1991 2 guys from Dallas, TX created what was known as the first computerized Fantasy Sports Application.  AutoStat was launched in the spring of 1991 by the company Fantasy Sports, Inc. for Baseball.  The software was a huge success, but the public was not quite ready to deal with comm ports, serial cables and 1200 Baud modems.   After 4 years, sadly Fantasy Sports, Inc. closed its doors.  

In early October 1995, what would become a popular fantasy hockey website was released by [[Molson|Molson Breweries]].<ref name="fantasy">{{cite web|url=http://strategyonline.ca/1995/10/16/11295-19951016/|title=Hockey Net in Canada: Molson scores with fantasy league|last=Summerfield|first=Patti|publisher=strategy (Brunico Communications)|date=16 October 1995| accessdate=2003-03-27}}</ref> It was part of the company's "I am Online" strategy and centred on its "[[I am Canadian]]" 
advertising campaign; it would focus on music, entertainment and hockey.<ref name="iamonline">{{cite news|title=Molson uncaps Internet site aimed at young adults|last=McHutchion|first=John|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=Toronto Star Newspapers| date=20 July 1995}}</ref> The website allowed visitors to register accounts and participate in hockey leagues of nine teams in which the visitor would be the general manager for one of those teams.<ref name="fantasy" /> The general manager would draft a team from a pool of NHL players, and could later negotiate trades with other teams in the league.<ref name="fantasy" /> Disputes would be arbitrated by a commissioner by [[email]].<ref name="fantasy" /> The site included daily updates of NHL statistics, and also featured content from the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]].<ref name="fantasy" /> On 24 May 1996, Molson Breweries won the International Digital Media Award for best website of 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://playbackonline.ca/1996/06/03/5401-19960603/|title=Int’l. Digital Media Awards|others=Playback Staff|publisher=Playback (Brunico Communications)|date=3 June 1996|accessdate=2003-03-27}}</ref>

Fantasy businesses began to migrate to the internet in the mid-1990s.  In 1997, two such sites that debuted were Commissioner.com and [[Rotowire|RotoNews.com]].

Commissioner.com launched on January 1, 1997 and first offered a fantasy baseball commissioner service that offered real-time statistics, league message boards, daily updated box scores and other features. Commissioner.com was sold to [[CBS SportsLine.com|SportsLine]] late in 1999 for $31 million in cash and stock.<ref name="sportsbusinessjournal.com">{{cite news | first=Russell | last=Adams | coauthors= | title=Peter Pezaris | date= | publisher=Street & Smiths | url =http://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=page.feature&featureId=710 | work =SportsBusiness Journal | pages = 
| accessdate = 2007-07-28 | language = }}</ref> The sale proved fantasy sports had grown from a mere hobby to big business. By 2003, Commissioner.com helped [[CBS SportsLine.com|SportsLine]] generate $11 million from fantasy revenue.<ref name="sportsbusinessjournal.com"/> Commissioner.com is now the fantasy sports engine behind the [[CBSSports.com]] fantasy area 
(after SportsLine was sold to CBS in 2004).

[[Rotowire|RotoNews.com]] also launched in January 1997 and published its first player note on February 16, 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rotowire.com/blog/20-years-ago-today/ |title=It was 20 years ago today |last=Schoenke |first=Peter |publisher=RotoWire.com |date=2017-02-17 |accessdate=2017-11-21 }}</ref>  RotoNews added additional value to fantasy sports players by creating player notes, which were snippets of information every time a player got hurt, traded, benched or had a news event that impacted his fantasy value - all search-able in a real-time database.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sean | last=Nolan | coauthors= | title=Access Magazine | date=1999-08-16 | publisher= | url =http://www.presstelegram.com/ | work =Long Beach Press-Telegram | page =15 | accessdate = 2007-07-24 | language = }}</ref>  Most sites today follow how RotoNews had a "news" and "analysis" element to each player update. {{citation needed|date=September 2015}}  Within two years RotoNews had become one of the top ten most trafficked sports sites on the web, according to Media Metrix, ranking higher than such sites as NBA.com<ref>Peter Schoenke. (n.d.). Retrieved May 31, 2018, from https://fsta.site-ym.com/page/schoenke</ref>.RotoNews.com was sold to [[Broadband Sports]] in 1999 and later survived as [[RotoWire.com]].

The growth in fantasy sports revenue attracted larger media players. [[Yahoo|Yahoo.com]] added fantasy sports in 1999 and offered most 
of its games for free - a largely new business model for fantasy sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/ReleaseDetail.cfm?ReleaseID=173646 |title=Yahoo! Sports Hits Home Run With Free Fantasy Baseball |accessdate=2007-10-28 |date=1999-02-23 |work=Yahoo! |publisher=Yahoo! }}</ref>  A trade group for the industry, the [[Fantasy Sports Trade Association]] was formed in 1998.

Other entries to the market during this era included Fanball.com, launched in 1999 by the parent company of Fantasy Football Weekly.<ref name="urlwire.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.urlwire.com/newsarchive/083199.html |title=Fanball.com, Inc. Announces the Launch of Fanball.com |accessdate=2007-10-28 |date=1999-08-31 |publisher=Fanball }}</ref>

An early survey of the fantasy sports market in the U.S. in 1999 showed 29.6 million people age 18 and older played fantasy 
games.  However, that figure was reduced in later years when it was determined the survey also included people who play NCAA bracket pools, which are not fantasy sports, since they involved picking teams, not individual players.<ref>{{cite news | first=Jeff | last=Zillgitt | coauthors= | title=We certainly live in a fantasy world | date=2000-02-28 | publisher= | url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/comment/jzcol53.htm | work =USA Today | pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-28 | language = }}</ref>

====Internet era====

While fantasy sports were fueled by the [[Dot-com bubble|dot-com]] boom of the Internet, there was a turbulent period when many of the high-flying Internet companies of the era crashed in 2001.  Fanball.com went bankrupt in 2001,<ref>{{cite news | first=Andrew | last=Tellijohn | coauthors= | title=Fanball stays in play | date= 2002-05-05| publisher=American City Business Journals | url =http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2002/05/06/story8.html | work =Minneapolis / St. Paul Business Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref> (later to re-emerge in 2001). RotoNews.com's parent company, [[Broadband Sports]], went out of business in 2001. The company would re-emerge as [[RotoWire.com]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

There were also different business models. [[RotoWire|RotoNews.com]] launched the Web's first free commissioner service in 1998, quickly becoming the largest league management service.<ref name="urlwire.com"/> [[Yahoo! Fantasy Sports|Yahoo.com]] became the first major media company to offer games for free in 1999. Due to the rising competition, Commissioner.com, which had charged as much as $300, offered its commissioner services for free starting with football in 2000.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

Two years later the trend reversed. Sportsline moved back to a pay model for commissioner services<ref>{{cite news | first=John | last=Hunt | coauthors= | title=You might have to pay to help you play | date=2002-03-12 | publisher=Gannett | url =https://www.usatoday.com/sports/bbw/2002-03-13/getting-started.htm | work =USA Today | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref> (which it largely still has today).  TheHuddle.com, a free site since 1997, started to charge for information.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Smaller Fantasy Football Web Sites Prove Popular for Information | date=2005-08-28 | publisher= | url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/222525/smaller_fantasy_football_web_sites_prove_popular_for_information/ | work =RedOrbit | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref> [[RotoWire.com]] moved from a free model to a pay model in 2001 as well.<ref>{{cite news | first=JOE | last=SALKOWSKI | coauthors= | title=Subscription Model Creeps Into More Gash-Needy Sites | date=2001-05-01 | publisher=Tribune Company | url =http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Subscription+Model+Creeps+Into+More+Gash-Needy+Sites-a079916132 | work =Chicago Tribune | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref> Despite the economic instability, fantasy sports started to become a mainstream hobby. In 2002, the [[NFL]] found that the average male surveyed spent 6.6 hours a week watching the NFL on TV; fantasy players surveyed said they watched 8.4 hours of NFL per week.<ref>{{cite news | first=Terry | last=Lefton | coauthors= | title=Survey results push nfl.com to increase fantasy content | date=2002-09-09 | publisher=Street & Smith's Sports Group | url =http://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=search.show_article&articleId=24518&keyword=fantasy%20sports%20chris%20russo%20NFL | work =Sports Business Journal | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-28 | language = }}</ref>  "This is the first time we've been able to demonstrate specifically that fantasy play drives TV viewing," said Chris Russo, the NFL's senior vice president. The NFL began running promotional television ads for fantasy football featuring current players for the first time. Previously fantasy sports had largely been seen in a negative light by the major sports leagues.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

Fantasy sports continued to grow with a 2003 [[Fantasy Sports Trade Association]] survey showing 15 million people playing fantasy football and spending about $150 a year on average, making it a $1.5 billion industry.<ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |coauthors= |title=Fantasy Sports Industry Now over 15 Million |date=2003-08-14 |publisher= |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2003_August_14/ai_106587252 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120711150417/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2003_August_14/ai_106587252 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-11 |work=Business Wire |pages= |accessdate=2007-10-28 |language= }}</ref> More recently a 2013 article by Forbes.com shows 32 million Americans spend $467 per person or about $15 billion in total playing. https://www.forbes.com/sites/briangoff/2013/08/20/the-70-billion-fantasy-football-market/#30a3709d755c

In autumn 2008, the [[Montana Lottery]], one of only four U.S. states to legalize [[sports betting]] at the time, began offering fantasy 
sports wagering for the first time.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.montanalottery.com/history |title=How it all started|publisher=montanalottery.com|accessdate=2015-09-18}}</ref>

Since 2012 there has been a boom of apps being built for fantasy. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Greg Greenhalgh Brendan Dwyer Brian Biggio|title=There's An App For That|journal=Journal of Applied Sport Management|date=Winter 2014|volume=Vol. 6|issue=No. 4|pages=23|url=js.sagamorepub.com/jasm/article/download/6093/4851|accessdate=10 October 2016}}</ref> These apps, and the nature of play within them, are changing the fantasy sports landscape and how users consume them.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

====Daily fantasy sports====
{{main|Daily fantasy sports}}


Daily fantasy sports (or DFS) contests are played across shorter periods of time, such as a single week of a season, rather than an entire season. Daily fantasy games are typically played as "contests" subject to an entry fee, which funds an advertised prize pool and an administrative fee is partially collected as revenue for the service.<ref name="nv-memo">{{cite web|title=Legality of Daily Fantasy Sports Under Nevada Law|url=http://gaming.nv.gov/modules/showdocument.aspx?documentid=10487|publisher=State of Nevada|accessdate=20 October 2015}}</ref>

Daily fantasy sports began to emerge in 2007 with the launch of Fantasy Sports Live<ref>{{cite web |url=https://rotogrinders.com/static/daily-fantasy-sports-timeline |title=The evolution of the daily fantasy sports industry |accessdate=2017-12-09 }}</ref>. In 2008, NBC launched SnapDraft; and FanDuel quickly became the prominent DFS site shortly after it launched in 2009<ref>{{cite web |url=https://rotogrinders.com/static/daily-fantasy-sports-timeline |title=The evolution of the daily fantasy sports industry |accessdate=2017-12-09 }}</ref>. DFS experienced a major increase in prominence in 2014 and 2015 with the dramatic growth of two competing services: [[DraftKings]] and [[FanDuel]]. Both received venture capital investments from various firms, including sports teams and broadcasters, and became known for running aggressive marketing campaigns with an emphasis on large cash prizes.<ref name=wp-dfs1>{{cite news|last1=Kilgore|first1=Adam|title=Daily fantasy sports Web sites find riches in Internet gaming law loophole|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/daily-fantasy-sports-web-sites-find-riches-in-internet-gaming-law-loophole/2015/03/27/92988444-d172-11e4-a62f-ee745911a4ff_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=March 27, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015}}</ref><ref name="wsj-dfs1">{{cite news|last1=Chernova|first1=Yuliya|title=FanDuel Raises $70 Million as Daily Fantasy Sports Battle Heats Up|date=September 2, 2014|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/09/02/fanduel-raises-70-million-as-daily-fantasy-sports-battle-heats-up/|accessdate=October 15, 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fantasy-sports-create-billion-dollar-startups-1436846402|title=Fantasy Sports Create Billion-Dollar Startups|author=Lora Kolodny|date=July 14, 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]}}</ref><ref name=sbj-pushes>{{cite news|title=Daily fantasy pushes to continue growth streak|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/03/16/Marketing-and-Sponsorship/Daily-fantasy.aspx|accessdate=October 8, 2015|work=Sports Business Journal}}</ref>

The legality of daily fantasy games has been challenged, with critics, as well as the state of Nevada, arguing that they closer-resemble [[proposition bet|proposition]] [[sports betting|wagering]] on athlete performance than a traditional fantasy sports game, while DraftKings' CEO has referred to its games as being similar to [[online poker]].<ref name="nv-memo"/><ref name=wp-dfs1/><ref name=lvrj-dkceo>{{cite news|title=AG: DraftKings CEO called daily fantasy sports 'a casino'|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/gambling/ag-draftkings-ceo-called-daily-fantasy-sports-casino|accessdate=19 October 2015|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal}}</ref> DFS providers have cited the UIGEA's exemptions of fantasy sports as being a general exception for their legality; their legality is subject to how individual states classify a game of chance.<ref name=bloomberg-sheerchutzpah>{{cite news|title=How Will the Government Change the Game for Daily Fantasy Sports?|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-15/how-will-the-government-change-the-game-for-daily-fantasy-sports-|accessdate=20 October 2015|work=Bloomberg News|date=15 October 2015}}</ref>

Daily Fantasy Sports have not historically offered in 5 states [Iowa, Arizona, Louisiana, Montana, Washington] that have laws stating a game that involves any chance is gambling. In addition several other states have murky legal environments for paid fantasy sports contests with negative AG opinions or in the case of Nevada, requiring a gambling license. As a result, Draftkings and Fanduel are active in only 39 states. Neither is currently accepting customers in Washington, Idaho, Montana, Arizona, Hawaii, Iowa, Louisiana, Alabama or Nevada. Additionally, Fanduel is not accepting customers from Texas. In his final remarks at the January 2016 FTSA conference in Dallas, Fantasy Sports Trade Association President Paul Charchian said "We need to formally legalize fantasy play in 50 states."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/chalk/story/_/id/14799449/daily-fantasy-dfs-legal-your-state-state-state-look|title=Daily fantasy sports state-by-state tracker|last=Rodenberg|first=Ryan|date=July 26, 2017|website=ESPN|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

However, since initial legal challenges, 19 states have since enacted laws confirming that DFS contests are legal games of skill.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gouker |first=Dustin |url=https://www.legalsportsreport.com/16802/ohio-sends-fantasy-sports-bill-governor/ |title=Ohio Sends Fantasy Sports Bill To Governor; Would Be 18th State With Law |work=Legal Sports Report |date=2017-12-05 |accessdate=2017-12-09 }}</ref>

==Industry overview==

===Size of the industry===

In May 2015, Australian research company research firm IBISWorld reported that fantasy sport was a $2B industry, experiencing 10.7% annual growth, and employing 4,386 people in 292 businesses.<ref name=IBISWorld>{{cite web|url= http://www.ibisworld.com/industry/fantasy-sports-services.html |title=Fantasy Sports Services in the US: Market Research Report|publisher=IBISWorld.com|accessdate=2015-09-18}}</ref>  

According to the Fantasy Sports Trade Association, Fantasy sports is a $7.22 billion industry with 59.3 million fantasy sports players in the United States and Canada as of 2016.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://fsta.org/press-release-fantasy-sports-now-a-7-billion-industry/ |title=antasy Sports Now a $7 Billion Industry<!lang> |language={$lang}</!lang> |publisher=FSTA |date=2017-06-23 |accessdate=2017-12-09 }}</ref>

===Growth of the market===

A prior study conducted by the FSTA in 2013, showed 33.5 million people age 12 and above in the U.S. with the 2011 FSTA Study showing 3.1 million people in Canada played fantasy sports.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Fantasy Sports Conference Demographic Survey Shows Continued Growth | date=2007-08-02 | publisher=PR Web | url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2007/8/prweb543818.htm | work = | pages = | accessdate = 2007-10-09 | language = }}</ref> A 
2006 study showed 22 percent of U.S. adult males 18 to 49 years old, with Internet access, play fantasy sports. Fantasy Sports 
is estimated to have a $3–$4 Billion annual economic impact across the sports industry.<ref>{{cite news | first=Stephen | 
last=Dorman | coauthors= | title=The fantasy football phenomenon | date=2006-08-03 | publisher= | url =http://www.theacorn.com/news/2006/0803/Sports/076.html | work =Agoura Hills Acorn | pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-27 | 
language = }}</ref>  Since 2011, yearly non-betting fantasy sports users have grown 25%.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title = The Hyper Growth Of Daily Fantasy Sports Is Going To Change Our Culture And Our Laws|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2015/09/16/the-hyper-growth-of-daily-fantasy-sports-is-going-to-change-our-culture-and-our-laws/|website = Forbes|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref> And with the help of media and the growing fantasy sports market, daily fantasy sports leagues FanDuel and DraftKings were able to generate over 300 million dollars in investments from companies like Comcast, NBC Sports, and Time Warner.<ref name=":0" />  The new development of daily fantasy sports is where major growth can be seen, "...the daily fantasy spending is where the numbers jump: $257 per year in 2015, while players only spent $5 in 2012."<ref>{{cite news|title = Fantasy Sports Spending Has Real Growth Spurt|url = http://time.com/money/4010096/fantasy-sports-spending-daily-growth-money/|website = MONEY.com|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref>

[[File:Fantasy_Sports_User_Growth.png|483x483px|Fantasy Sports User Growth]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fsta.org/research/industry-demographics/|title=Industry Demographics {{!}} FSTA|website=fsta.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>

====International growth of fantasy sports====

The fantasy sports hobby has also moved beyond the U.S. Fantasy leagues for soccer, cricket and other sports have come up. For example, according to a 2008 study by Paris, France research company Ipsos, the number of British fantasy sports players aged 16–64 is estimated to range between 5.5 and 7.5 million.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}  Of those, 80 percent of these players participate in fantasy soccer.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2009/09/Issue-6/Sponsorships-Advertising-Marketing/Fantasy-Players-Seen-As-Big-Spenders-In-Key-Consumer-Categories.aspx | title = Fantasy Players Seen As Big Spenders In Key Consumer Categories | accessdate = 2011-02-17 | last = Fisher | first = Eric | date = September 21, 2009 | work = Sports Business Daily | publisher = Street & Smith's | quote = Twenty-two percent of the U.K. survey respondents said they play fantasy sports}}</ref>  The current leading fantasy sports provider in the UK is the English Premier League, which tallied more than 4 million users for the 2016/17 season.<ref>[https://fantasy.premierleague.com/ Fantasy Premier League Official site]</ref> In comparison to the United States, the UK has roughly 5% of the population participating, whereas the U.S. has about 10% of its population playing fantasy sports.<ref>{{cite web|title = European Daily Fantasy Sports On Verge Of Huge Growth|url = http://www.legalsportsreport.com/1966/european-daily-fantasy-sports-growth/|website = Legal Sports Report|accessdate = 2015-10-11}}</ref>

===Demographics===

The FSTA industry group collected and presented statistics showing the percentage of fantasy sports players compared to the 
general population in the United States and Canada (Age 12+).<ref name=fstastats>{{cite web|url= http://fsta.org/research/industry-demographics/ |title=Industry demographics|publisher=fsta.org|accessdate=2015-09-18}}</ref> 

In regards to the consumption habits of fantasy managers, demographic and psychographic research has found the average participant is: male (80%), Caucasian (91%), holds a bachelor's degree or higher (70%), has more than five years of internet experience (84%), earns an average of $94,000, and spends approximately $200 on entry fees and other fantasy related costs. Fantasy players were also stronger consumers of the following products compared to the general population: beer/alcohol, fast food, airline travel, video games, sports periodicals, athletic shoes, cell phones, and credit card usage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://digitalcommons.kent.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1017&context=sport|title=The Journal of Sport|last=Burton|first=Rick|last2=Hall|first2=Kevin|date=2013|website=Digital Commons Kent State University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|last3=Paul|first3=Rodney}}</ref>

===Projections for the market===

In September 2015, Forbes reported that Eilers Research was projecting that daily fantasy games will generate around $2.6 billion in entry fees this year and grow 41% annually, reaching $14.4 billion in 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2015/09/16/the-hyper-growth-of-daily-fantasy-sports-is-going-to-change-our-culture-and-our-laws/ |title=The Hyper Growth Of Daily Fantasy Sports Is Going To Change Our Culture And Our Laws|publisher=forbes.com|date=2015-09-16|accessdate=2015-09-18}}</ref>

===Trade associations===

The [[Fantasy Sports Trade Association]] was formed in 1997 to represent the growing industry.  Beginning in 2000, the FSTA has honored past members and contributors to fantasy sports with induction into its Hall of Fame.

The [[Fantasy Sports Writers Association]] was formed in 2004 to represent the growing numbers of journalists covering fantasy 
sports exclusively.<ref name="bizj">{{cite news | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/albany/stories/2007/05/28/focus4.html| title=Growing fantasy sports scene is big business | work=[[The Business Review]] | date=May 28, 2007 | 
accessdate=2013-02-06}}</ref>  The [[Fantasy Sports Association]] was formed in 2006 as a rival trade group, but folded in 2010.

==Legal issues in the United States==

===Federal law related to fantasy gaming===

The [[Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006]] (UIGEA), was enacted as part of the "American Values Agenda" of 2006 and was added as an amendment to the unrelated [[SAFE PORT ACT]].<ref name="CNN">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2006/POLITICS/06/28/mg.thu/ |title=House GOP promotes its "American Values Agenda" | publisher=cnn.com| date=2006-06-28| accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref>  The UIGEA generally prohibits funds transfers to businesses engaged in unlawful internet wagering.<ref name="law.cornell.edu">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5361 | title= 31 U.S. Code § 5361 - Congressional findings and purpose}}</ref>  However the UIGEA does not itself define unlawful internet wagering, and expressly refrains from altering the legality of any underlying conduct other than funds transfers.<ref name="https">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5361 | title= 31 U.S. Code § 5361(b)- No modification of existing law}}</ref>

While the act doesn't alter the legality of any particular activity permitted or prohibited under other laws, it does contain some express exemptions to its funds transfer prohibitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5362 | title= 31 U.S. Code § 5362- Definitions - Bet or Wager}}</ref>  One of these exemptions from the UIGEA prohibitions is for fantasy sports that meet certain criterial.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5362 | title= 31 U.S. Code § 5362(1)(E)(vii)- Definitions - Bet or Wager - Fantasy excluded from definition}}</ref> Specifically, fantasy sports that are based on teams of real multiple athletes from multiple real world teams, that have prizes established before the event starts, that use the skill of participants to determine the outcome, are exempted from the definition of a bet or wager that is the basis for requiring banks to identify and block funds transfers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/31/5364 | title= 31 U.S. Code § 5364 - Policies and procedures to identify and prevent restricted transactions}}</ref>  According to Congressman Leach, an author of the UIGEA, exemptions, particularly one for fantasy sports, were included to relieve the burden of enforcement on banks and the UIGEA does not make fantasy sports legal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2015/10/12/former-congressman-says-dfs-is-cauldron-of-daily-betting |title=Author of anti-gambling law says "sheer chutzpah" for daily fantasy sites to claim legitimacy |publisher=usnews.com |date=2015-10-12 |accessdate=2015-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117024332/http://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2015/10/12/former-congressman-says-dfs-is-cauldron-of-daily-betting |archivedate=2015-11-17 |df= }}</ref>

Because the UIGEA exempted fantasy sports from its definition of a bet or wager, there is a misconception that fantasy sports were made legal by the UIGEA.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/04/06/fantasy-sports-vs-illegal-gambling-wheres-the-line-commentary.html | title=Fantasy Sports vs Illegal Gambling Where is the Line | publisher=cnbc.com | date=2015-04-06 | accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref>  However the UIGEA is not a criminal gambling statute, and it specifically does not alter any criminal gambling laws and thus does not make fantasy sports legal.<ref name="https"/> Federal criminal gambling statutes are found in Title 18 of U.S. Code, such as the Federal Wire Act 18 U.S. Code § 1084 (which prohibits interstate sports wagering) and the Illegal Gambling Business Act 18 U.S. Code § 1955 (which prohibits the interstate conduct of wagering activity prohibited under state law).<ref name="cornell1">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1084 | title= 18 U.S. Code § 1084}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1955 | title= 18 U.S. Code § 1955}}</ref> By contrast, the UIGEA is found in Title 31 with other anti-money laundering and financial crimes statutes.<ref name="law.cornell.edu"/>

===State laws related to fantasy gaming===

Whether state laws can regulate fantasy sports depends on whether fantasy sports are a form of sports wagering under federal law.  This is because the Federal Wire Act preempts state law and prohibits the conduct of sports wagering in interstate or foreign commerce.<ref name="cornell1"/>  Additionally, with regard to intrastate commerce, the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection act prohibits states from authorizing and regulating any wagering, lottery, betting, sweepstakes or other wagering scheme that is based directly or indirectly on games in which professional or amateur athletes participate or on the performance of any athletes in such games.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/28/3702 | title= 28 U.S. Code § 3702 - Unlawful sports gambling}}</ref>

In the event that fantasy sports are not deemed to be a form of sports wagering, then states may have a role in determining their legality.  Under most state laws, lotteries are illegal only if they involve three elements: an entry fee (known as "consideration"), a prize (a "reward", in legal terms) and chance.  Whether fantasy sports are a lottery varies from state to state and hinges on the definition of "chance" that the state interprets.  For some states, if skill dominates the outcome of the event, then the contest is legal, and passes what's called the "dominant factor test".  Other states with a stricter definition of chance, called "any chance test", have made fantasy football illegal.<ref name=forbes1>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/marcedelman/2013/09/03/is-it-legal-to-play-fantasy-football-for-money/ |title=Is It Legal To Play Fantasy Football For Money? |publisher=forbes.com |date=2013-09-03 |accessdate=2015-09-23}}</ref>

Several states have clarified that paid fantasy sports contests are games of skill and exempt from gambling laws, beginning with Maryland in 2012<ref>{{cite news |last=Gouker |first=Dustin |url=https://www.legalsportsreport.com/12544/maryland-comptroller-dfs-reguation/ |title=Maryland Comptroller Officially Implements Fantasy Sports Regulations |work=Legal Sports Report |date=2017-01-03 }}</ref>.

One exception is the state of Nevada, which has an exemption in PASPA to allow for sports betting. The Nevada attorney general issued an opinion that found Daily Fantasy Sports to be a form of sports wagering, similar to the current wagering offered by Nevada Sports Books.<ref name="gaming.nv.gov">{{cite web|url=http://gaming.nv.gov/modules/showdocument.aspx?documentid=10487 | title=Legality of Daily Fantasy Sports Under Nevada Law | date=2015-10-16}}</ref>  The opinions states that Daily Fantasy Sports are not illegal in Nevada; however, a sports pool license is required to conduct the activity in Nevada.<ref name="gaming.nv.gov"/>

Several Attorneys General have also issued opinions that Daily Fantasy Sports are a form of sports wagering. A Florida state attorney general's opinion in 1991 called into doubt the legality of fantasy football contests, but companies have operated in the state without any legal action. Since then nine other AGs have issued options, statements or formal opinions that equate DFS with gambling.

However, several other  Attorneys General have issued opinions that DFS are legal games of skill. In August 2015 in Kansas, due to uncertainty with the state’s Racing and Gaming Commission position,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansas.com/news/politics-government/article1318033.html#/tabPane=tabs-2e561a63-1 |title=Fantasy sports betting always has been illegal in Kansas, gaming commission counsel says |publisher=The Wichita Eagle |date=2014-08-28 |accessdate=2015-09-23}}</ref> the state’s attorney general issued an opinion that daily fantasy sports was a skill game and thus permitted under state law.  Kansas Gov. Sam Brownback signed legislation a month later authorizing fantasy gaming.<ref name=calvinayre>{{cite web|url=http://calvinayre.com/2015/09/02/business/michigan-gaming-regulator-says-fantasy-sports-illegal/|title=Michigan gaming regulator says fantasy sports are illegal |publisher=calvinayre.com |date=2015-09-02 |accessdate=2015-09-23}}</ref> The Attorneys General of West Virginia and Rhode Island have also issued opinions that clarified the legality of DFS and paid fantasy sports.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gouker |first=Dustin |url=https://www.legalsportsreport.com/10703/fantasy-sports-west-virginia-legality/ |title=West Virginia Attorney General On Fantasy Sports: State ‘Does Not Prohibit’ Contests |work=Legal Sports Report |date=2017-07-11 }}</ref>

As of December 2017, 18 states have followed Maryland to clarify that DFS and paid fantasy sports are legal contests of skill. These states include Kansas (2015), Indiana, Virginia, Missouri, Massachusetts, Colorado, Tennessee, New York, Mississippi (2016), Arkansas, New Jersey, Vermont, New Hampshire, Ohio, Maine, Vermont, Delaware, Pennsylvania, Connecticut (2017).<ref>{{cite news |last=Gouker |first=Dustin |url=https://www.legalsportsreport.com/16802/ohio-sends-fantasy-sports-bill-governor/ |title=Ohio Sends Fantasy Sports Bill To Governor; Would Be 18th State With Law |work=Legal Sports Report |date=2017-12-05 |accessdate=2017-12-09 }}</ref>.

In September 2015, New Jersey Congressman Frank Pallone, who has championed legal sports betting in his state, requested a hearing from the House Energy and Commerce Committee to examine the relationship between the professional sports leagues and the fantasy sports companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/i-team/congressman-gambling-fantasy-sports-article-1.2369123 |title=N.J. congressman Frank Pallone slams pro leagues for opposing gambling while profiting off fantasy sports  |publisher=nydailynews.com |date=2015-09-21 |accessdate=2015-09-23}}</ref> The hearing was held in May 2015 and resulted in no proposed legislation, changes or regulations of fantasy sports.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gouker |first=Dustin |url=https://www.legalsportsreport.com/9985/congress-and-action-on-daily-fantasy-sports/ |title=After Hearing, Don’t Expect Congress To Get Involved With Daily Fantasy Sports |work=Legal Sports Report |date=2016-05-11 }}</ref>

===Legal cases related to use of player statistics===

There have been other legal cases involving fantasy sports and the use of professional athletes' statistics for purposes of scoring.

====STATS, Inc. vs. NBA====

In 1996, [[STATS, Inc.]], a major statistical provider to fantasy sports companies, won a court case, along with [[Motorola]], 
on appeal against the [[NBA]] in which the NBA was trying to stop [[STATS, Inc.|STATS]] from distributing in game score 
information via a special wireless device created by Motorola.  The victory played a large part in defending other cases where 
sports leagues have tried to suppress live in-game information from their events being distributed by other outlets.<ref>[http://legal.web.aol.com/decisions/dldecen/nba.html NBA Lawsuit - AOL.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702231859/http://legal.web.aol.com/decisions/dldecen/nba.html |date=July 2, 2007 }}</ref> The victory also accelerated the market for 
real-time statistics which were largely fueled by the growth of the fantasy sports industry.<ref>[[Alan Schwarz]]: ''The 
Numbers Game : Baseball's Lifelong Fascination with Statistics'' [[Thomas Dunne Books]] p. 192, {{ISBN|0-312-32222-4}}</ref>

====CDM vs. MLBAM====

The development of fantasy sports produced tension between fantasy sports companies and professional leagues and players 
associations over the rights to player profiles and statistics. The players associations of the major sports leagues believed that fantasy games using player names were subject to licensing due to the right of publicity of the players involved. Since the player names were being used as a group, the players had assigned their publicity rights to the players association who then signed licensing deals. During the 1980s and 1990s many companies signed licensing deals with the player associations, but some companies did not. The issue came to a head with the lawsuit of [[MLBAM|Major League Baseball Advanced Media (MLBAM)]], [[Major League Baseball|MLB's]] Internet company, vs. St. Louis-based CBC Distribution and Marketing Inc., the parent company of [[Fanball|CDM Sports]]. When CBC was denied a new licensing agreement with MLBAM (they had acquired the rights from the baseball players' association) for its fantasy baseball game, CBC filed suit.

CBC argued that intellectual property laws and so-called "right of publicity" laws don't apply to the statistics used in fantasy sports.<ref name="sports.espn.go.com">{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Fantasy leagues permitted to use MLB names, stats | date=2006-08-08 | publisher= | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=2543720 | work =ESPN | pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-28 | language = }}</ref> The [[Fantasy Sports Trade Association|FSTA]] filed an [[amicus curiae]] in support of CBC, also arguing that if MLBAM won the lawsuit it would have a dramatic impact on the industry, which was largely ignored by the major sports leagues for years while a number of smaller entrepreneurs grew it into a multibillion-dollar industry, and a ruling could allow the MLBAM to have a monopoly over the industry.

"This will be a defining moment in the fantasy sports industry," said Charlie Wiegert, executive vice president of CBC. "The other leagues are all watching this case. If MLB prevailed, it just would have been a matter of time before they followed up. Their player unions are just waiting for the opportunity."<ref>{{cite news | first=Michael | last=McCarthy | coauthors= | title=Fantasy leagues can use baseball stats | date=2006-08-08 | publisher= | url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/2006-08-08-fantasy-statistics_x.htm | work =USA Today | pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-28 | language = }}</ref>

CBC won the lawsuit as U.S. District Court Judge Mary Ann Medler ruled that statistics are part of the public domain and can be used at no cost by fantasy companies.  "The names and playing records of major-league baseball players as used in CBC's fantasy games are not copyrightable," Medler wrote. "Therefore, federal copyright law does not pre-empt the players' claimed right of publicity."<ref name="sports.espn.go.com"/>

The 8th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the decision in October 2007.  "It would be strange law that a person would not have a First Amendment right to use information that is available to everyone," a three-judge panel said in its ruling.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Fantasy Sports Win Right to Player Names, Statistics | date=2007-10-16 | publisher= | url =https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=aVMAY0beLSoA&refer=home | work =Bloomerberg| pages = | accessdate = 2007-07-28 | language = }}</ref>

The U.S. Supreme Court upheld the 8th Circuit Court's decision by declining to hear the case in June 2008.<ref>{{cite news | first=Greg | last=Stohr | coauthors= | title=Baseball Rebuffed by U.S. Supreme Court on Fantasy Rights | date=2008-06-02 | publisher= | url =https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=a.5jCrvS31Uo&refer=home | work =Bloomberg | pages = | accessdate = 2008-06-02 | language = }}</ref>
